titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Carl H. Dahlstrom collection of Blizzard of 1888 photographs V1988.034
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Weatherly Stephan
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-11-28T15:15-0500

did.unittitle: Carl H. Dahlstrom collection of Blizzard of 1888 photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Carl H. Dahlstrom collection of Blizzard of 1888 photographs dates from 1888 and contains 16 items. Photographs in the collection are modern copy prints of black-and-white negatives taken by a Dr. Levison following the blizzard. Images are located in the Boerum Hill and Downtown neighborhoods of Brooklyn. The collection includes street scenes which show the impact of the blizzard on the buildings, streets, and elevated train tracks. Several images show horse-drawn sleds and carriages in the streets. The collection also includes two photographed maps which track the storm's path in the Northern Atlantic Ocean.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids note
otherfindaid.p: Item-level description and digital versions of images from the collection are available for searching via the image database in the library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Carl H. Dahlstrom collection of Blizzard of 1888 photographs, V1988.034, Box number, Object ID number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Fully processed to the item level.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: All items in this collection have entered the public domain. For information on securing rights to publish or reproduce, please see the Brooklyn Historical Society Reproduction Rights Policy.
